items.title: Truck driver who caused Humboldt Broncos crash one step away from deportation, lawyer says
items.summary_auto: The Immigration and Refugee Board is still considering a previous application to restore Sidhu's permanent resident status on humanitarian grounds.

items.title: Developing anti-drone weapons at home? Experts weigh in on bizarre Ontario explosives investigation
items.summary_auto: As four people remain in custody after being accused of storing materials that could be made into explosives at an Ontario house, some engineers say it’s ‘not unusual’ for scientists to have at-home labs, but cite a slew of safety concerns.

items.title: Government tables bill giving Build Canada Homes power to acquisition land
items.summary_auto: The federal government introduced legislation that would enshrine its housing agency as a Crown corporation on Thursday, giving it land acquisition authority as well as the ability to partner with private developers — as questions remain over the number of units it intends to build.

items.title: Some U.S. alcohol will return to SAQ shelves amid import ban
items.summary_auto: Starting on Feb. 12, the Quebec government will authorize the province's liquor board to restock some U.S. products whose quality might start declining as of March 2027.

items.title: Mother believed to be 'willing participant' in suspected murder-suicide, B.C. coroner's inquest hears
items.summary_auto: RCMP say the parents found dead along with their two children in Prince Rupert had recorded a video will in the days leading to their deaths.

items.title: Calgary man facing extradition in Ryan Wedding drug case a 'loyal soldier,' Crown says at bail hearing
items.summary_auto: Calgarian Allistair Chapman, accused of working for an alleged Canadian drug lord and helping to set up the murder of an FBI informant, was described by the prosecution as a “loyal soldier” who should not be granted bail.

items.title: Federal public servants called back to office 4 days a week starting this summer
Newly released Epstein email appears to confirm photo of Virginia Giuffre, former prince Andrew
items.summary_auto: Ten months after Virginia Giuffre's death by suicide, a newly released email appears to support her claims that she met and posed for a photograph with Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor.

items.title: What to expect from Bad Bunny’s Super Bowl halftime show? Dancing, culture and a side of politics
items.summary_auto: Culture war commentary has swirled around the upcoming Super Bowl halftime performance since Puerto Rican superstar Bad Bunny was named as the headliner. That’s only increased after music stars, including Bad Bunny, used the Grammy Awards stage on Sunday to call out immigration enforcement in the U.S.

items.title: Tate McRae responds to backlash over U.S. Olympics ad: 'Y'all know I'm Canada down'
Court releases police video of Ottawa city councillor on trial for drunk driving
items.summary_auto: A cellblock video depicting Ottawa city Coun. Matthew Luloff twice testing double the legal blood-alcohol limit after his arrest for suspected impaired driving has now been released to the media, two weeks after it was shown during his trial.

items.title: David Furnish, husband of Elton John, accuses Daily Mail of homophobia in U.K. privacy trial
items.summary_auto: Canadian producer David Furnish, British singer Elton John's husband, told London's High Court on Thursday that the publisher of the Daily Mail had unlawfully obtained information about ​them, including information stolen from their friend Prince Harry. He also accused the publisher's titles of being 'actively homophobic' about their relationship.

items.title: Authorities investigating Nancy Guthrie's disappearance say they're taking ransom note seriously
items.summary_auto: Investigators believe the missing mother of Today show host Savannah Guthrie is "still out there," but they have not identified any suspects, officials in Arizona said Thursday.

items.title: Heated rivalry cools after Montreal company gets shout-out for viral jacket
items.summary_auto: A Montreal-based streetwear company, after sounding the alarm, is now being credited for producing the original white fleece that was modified to create a viral jacket worn in the hit series Heated Rivalry.

items.title: Start of Frank Stronach's sex assault trial in Toronto stalls as lawyer argues complainants possibly coached
items.summary_auto: The start of the sex assault trial for billionaire businessman Frank Stronach has stalled again as his lawyer argued in Toronto court Thursday that some of the complainants may have been coached during preparatory meetings with the Crown. The new date for proceedings to begin is Feb. 12.

items.title: Supreme Court to hear long-standing case about Air Canada's advertised pricing
items.summary_auto: The Supreme Court of Canada has agreed to hear arguments on a class-action lawsuit that alleged Air Canada charged passengers more than the advertised ticket price.

items.title: Fact check: Is Prime Minister Mark Carney in the Epstein files?
items.summary_auto: CBC’s fact-check team searched for Mark Carney’s name in the U.S. Justice Department’s Epstein Library. Here’s what we found.

items.title: Trump administration moves to end job protections for about 50,000 federal workers
items.summary_auto: The Donald Trump administration on Thursday finalized its overhaul of the U.S. government's civil service system, ​according to a government statement, which would give the president the power to hire and fire an estimated 50,000 career federal employees.

items.title: Hospital attack kills 22 in southern Sudan as famine threatens more of war-torn Darfur region
items.summary_auto: Famine is threatening more areas in war-torn Sudan's western Darfur region, a global hunger monitoring group said Thursday as an attack by paramilitary forces on a military hospital in the country's south killed 22 people, including the hospital's director and three members of its medical staff.

items.title: Ontario toy builder for sick kids finished 50th dollhouse days before dying of cancer
items.summary_auto: After being diagnosed with Stage 4 prostate cancer during the pandemic, the daughters of Vince Giannotti say building the miniature homes gave him peace right up until the end.

items.title: Search underway for man, 39, after woman violently taken from Pimicikamak Cree Nation home: RCMP
items.summary_auto: A 20-year-old woman is believed to be in immediate danger after she was "violently removed" from her home in Pimicikamak Cree Nation by a 39-year-old man in a case of intimate partner violence, Manitoba RCMP say.

items.title: Canadian hockey star Gavin McKenna allegedly struck man in the face during altercation, police say
items.summary_auto: In a news release issued late Wednesday, the State College Police Department said McKenna, 18, faces four charges including felony aggravated assault, simple assault, harassment and disorderly conduct after an altercation near Pennsylvania State University's main campus.

items.title: Quebec teen faces terrorism charge after allegedly promoting neo-Nazi group ideology
items.summary_auto: A teenager from the Quebec City area has been charged with a terrorism-related offence. The teen allegedly used social media to promote the violent ideology of a group known as Atomwaffen Division, according to the RCMP.

items.title: U.S., Russia agree to re-establish military-to-military dialogue after 4-year pause
items.summary_auto: The U.S. and Russia has agreed to re-establish high-level military dialogue for the first time in more than four years in another sign of warming relations between the two countries since U.S. President Donald Trump returned to office and sought to end the war in Ukraine.

items.title: How Team Canada stacks up against its Winter Olympic rivals
items.summary_auto: After a 2022 Olympic performance that saw a high total medal count but a 30-year low in gold finishes, Team Canada is looking to put more athletes on the podium at the Milano-Cortina Winter Games. These charts show how Canada stacks up against its competition.

items.title: Who are the Toronto police officers accused of assisting organized crime?
Still moving: How a Cranbrook program is helping seniors avoid falls by staying active and social
items.summary_auto: A twice-a-week exercise program in Cranbrook is helping residents in the Kootenay community avoid falls.

items.title: British PM Starmer apologizes for appointing Mandelson, but says diplomat lied about Epstein ties
items.summary_auto: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer apologized to the victims of Jeffrey Epstein on Thursday and said he ​was sorry for having appointed Peter Mandelson as U.S. ambassador, who was a close friend of the late sex offender.

items.title: Manitoba still faces challenge in curbing measles a year into outbreak: community health prof
items.summary_auto: It's been one year since the first measles cases in the latest outbreak were reported in Manitoba — and there's no sign the spread of the highly contagious disease is slowing.

items.title: Scientists, conservationists warn against closing N.B. fish research facility
items.summary_auto: The Wolastoqey Nation in New Brunswick and Atlantic salmon scientists and conservationists are criticizing the federal decision to close the Mactaquac Biodiversity Facility, which is mainly made up of a hatchery in French Village, below the Mactaquac Dam on the St. John River.

items.title: Oh baby! Some vintage names are making a comeback as seen throughout N.L. in 2025
items.summary_auto: Your grandparents names are making a comeback in Newfoundland and Labrador, following the 100-year trend.

items.title: Experts urge Ontario to learn from Eglinton Crosstown communications missteps
items.summary_auto: Transit experts and opposition critics say the Ontario government has to learn from its communications mistakes on the Eglinton Crosstown LRT to ensure the rollout of the remaining pieces of its multi-billion dollar transit expansion have public buy-in.

items.title: Mexican authorities seeking to speak with Canadian mining firm over kidnapped employees
items.summary_auto: The attorney general for the Mexican state of Sinaloa says she wants to speak with officials from a Canadian mining firm whose employees were kidnapped by a suspected faction of the Sinaloa cartel.

items.title: Moltbook claims to be a social network for AI bots. But humans are behind its rapid growth
items.summary_auto: It's branded as the world's first social network for AI bots. But just a week after its launch, the tech world is in fierce debate over Moltbook — and the extent to which human beings are responsible for the viral website's rapid growth.

items.title: She found out she had cancer while pregnant. Experts say earlier screening needed in Quebec
items.summary_auto: Statistics from the Canadian Cancer Society show Quebec has the highest incidence rate of cancer in the country. For one woman, her diagnosis came during what should have been one of the happiest moments in her life — while she was pregnant.

items.title: Grammy winner Alessia Cara lends her voice — and support — to Canada's Olympic dreams
items.summary_auto: After wrapping up a world tour for her fourth studio album, Alessia Cara has found herself on a new stage. The Brampton-born performer will kick off CBC’s coverage of the Olympic Games as the narrator of The Gold Within: Family & Fire.
